title: Vikings season 6 new cast member keeps dropping hints in BTS pictures
text:
Andrei Claude has shared behind-the-scenes snaps from filming on the final season (Picture: Instagram)

Vikings star Andrei Claude has been dropping teasers ahead of the final season.

We’re getting closer to the launch of season six in a couple of months time, and actor Alexander Ludwig has already teased the ‘insanity’ to come in the episodes ahead.

Andrei’s character Ganbaatar will become an ally to Ivar (Alex Høgh Andersen) in the new season of the hit historical show.

Sharing a picture of himself roaring into the action in the latest trailer for the show, he added the caption: ‘And did I mention that we’re not the friendliest of people?’

While filming the thrilling episodes, he has been blessing fans with behind-the-scenes snaps of the cast on set.

As well as chilling out with Alex in between takes he has given us a sneak peek at the lavish sets that will appear in season six, including a terrifying looking ceiling decoration made up of antlers.

In another snap from September this year, a long wooden table laden with candles and goblets can be seen, highlighting the attention to detail that goes into Vikings.

There was also a glimpse at a ‘new breed’ of Viking that was coming to cause trouble in season six.

Meanwhile stars Katheryn Winnick and Alex Høgh Andersen have teased their favourite scenes from the upcoming season, which includes an ‘epic’ battle.

Katheryn, who plays Lagertha, said: ‘I guess my most memorable battle has to be Lagertha’s next battle in season six.

‘It is epic, took weeks to rehearse, lots of blood, sweat and tears.

‘It is definitely going to be something you have never seen before.’

Alex explained: ‘My favourite battle scene when shooting Vikings is from an episode called Homeland.

‘My character, Ivar The Boneless, is charging into battle, and he’s really eager to get there, and yet when he finally arrives he gets knocked off the chariot.

‘Straight away he finds himself all along on the battlefield, facing a hundred Saxon soldiers.’

Fondly recalling the moment, he laughed: ‘We shot that scene for 10 hours a day, two days in a row, in the pouring rain, and I was covered in blood from head to toe, screaming all day long. But that was tonnes of fun.’
